front.title: Automated Where Are You From in Multilateral Federations

abstract.t: This document introduces a extension to the CTAP2 protocol that allows the storage of enterprise federation credentials and the enumeration of their corresponding identity providers.

section.name: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.
The term "byte" is used in its now-customary sense as a synonym for "octet".
This document makes use of the following terminology:

dd.t: An Authenticator is software that implements the CTAP protocol and is able to create new credentials and make assertions on request. It interacts with a Client through a communication channel like CTAPHID, which builds on top of USB HID.
A Client is software that implements the client-side part of the CTAP protocol. It acts as a middleman between a Authenticator and a Relying Party.

A Relying Party (RP) is a web-service one can authenticate to using the FIDO authentication protocol. It communicates indirectly with an Authenticator through the Client and is responsible for initiating a authentication ceremony.

Confidentiality relates to the state of data in which only authorized entities can comprehend its content. Typically, this is ensured through encryption, where only the possessor of the correct secret key can decrypt the data and gain access to its actual content.

Integrity pertains to the condition of data wherein no unauthorized alterations have occurred. Unintended modifications may occur inadvertently, such as a bit-flip resulting from hardware failure, or intentionally by an adversary with access to the data. The concept of "protecting data integrity" encompasses the ability to identify undesired changes before they can impact a system in any conceivable manner.

Authenticity denotes the ability to confirm that specific data has been generated by a particular source. This validation can be implemented through cryptographic concepts such as digital signatures or Message Authentication Codes. Frequently, a single cryptographic primitive can be employed to ensure both integrity and authenticity.

section.name: CTAP2 Extension
section.t: The following section introduces a extension for that adds a new field (idpId) which marks a credential as belonging to an identity provider.

section.name: Feature detection
section.t: This registration extension allows relying parties to specify an federation entity when creating a credential.

section.name: Client extension input
section.t: create(): A single USVString specifying the federation entity.

section.name: Client extension processing
section.t: If this extension is present in an authenticatorMakeCredential request:

list.t:
Verify that the fedEntity string value is valid:
TODO: verification criteria depend on the format (do we want UUID v4/v7 ?)

section.t: NOTE: For non-discoverable credentials, the fedEntity has no effect on the authenticators behaviour.

section.name: Client extension output
section.t: None. The authenticator returns the result in the authenticator extension output.

section.name: Authenticator extension input
section.t: The platform sends the authenticatorMakeCredential request with the following CBOR map entry in the "extensions" field to the authenticator:
NOTE: The extension SHOULD be ignored for non-discoverable credentials.

section.name: Authenticator extension processing
section.t: The authenticator checks whether the authenticatorMakeCredential's options.rk option is present and true. If so, the authenticator stores the given information with the created credential. If not, the authenticator SHOULD ignore the extension.

section.name: Authenticator extension output
section.t: If the authenticator has set the extensions value for the credential:
Else:

section.name: CTAP2 efed pinUvAuthToken permission
section.t: TODO: Maybe we can just use the same permission a credential management
The following pinUvAuthToken permission extends the list of existing pinUvAuthTokens.

texttable.c: This allows the pinUvAuthToken to be used with the authenticatorFederationManagement command. The rpId parameter is ignored for this permission.

section.name: Prototype authenticatorFederationManagement (0x42)
section.t: This command is used by the platform to manage federated credentials on the authenticator.
It takes the following input parameters:

texttable.c: PIN/UV protocol version selected by platform.
Result of calling authenticate(pinUvAuthToken, Prototype authenticatorFederationManagement (0x42))

section.t: The list of sub commands for credential management is:
On success, authenticator returns the following structure in its response:

texttable.c: total number of IdPs present on the authenticator

section.name: enumerateIdPBegin (0x01)
section.t: Following operations are preformed to enumerate the identity providers present on the authenticator:

list.t: Optionally, the platform gets a pinUvAuthToken from the authenticator with the efed permission.

The Platform sends a authenticatorEnumerateIdP command with the following parameters:
pinUvAuthProtocol (0x01): as selected when getting the shared secret (Optional). pinUvAuthParam (0x02): authenticate(pinUvAuthToken, authenticatorFederationManagement (0x42)) (Optional).

Authenticator on receiving such request performs following procedures:
If pinUvAuthParam is missing from the input map, go to 6. If pinUvAuthProtocol is not supported, return CTAP1_ERR_INVALID_PARAMETER. Authenticator calls verify(pinUvAuthToken, authenticatorFederationManagement (0x42), pinUvAuthParam). If pinUvAuthParam verification fails, authenticator returns CTAP2_ERR_PIN_AUTH_INVALID error. The authenticator verifies that the pinUvAuthToken has the efed permission. If not, return CTAP2_ERR_PIN_AUTH_INVALID. If no discoverable credentials exist on this authenticator, return CTAP2_ERR_NO_IDPS. Locate all credentials that are eligible for retrieval under the specified criteria:
Locate all discoverable credentials that are created by this authenticator that have the fedEntity property. Create an applicable credentials list populated with the located credentials. Iterate through the applicable credentials list, and if credential protection for a credential is marked as userVerificationRequired or userVerificationOptionalWithCredentialIDList, and the pinUvAuthParam is missing from the input map, remove that credential from the applicable credentials list. If the applicable credentials list is empty, return CTAP2_ERR_NO_IDPS. Let numberOfIdPs be the number of applicable credentials found.
Authenticator returns an authenticatorFederationManagement response with following parameters:
rpId (0x01): Text String, relying party id. idpId (0x02): Text String, the content of fedEntity. totalIdps (0x03): Total number of IdPs present on the authenticator. This can vary depending on if a pinUvAuthParam was sent with the request.

Platform on receiving more than 1 totalIdps, performs following procedure for (totalIdps - 1 ) number of times:
Platform sends authenticatorFederationManagement command with following parameters:
subCommand (0x01): enumerateIdPsGetNextIdP (0x02).
Authenticator on receiving such enumerateIdPsGetNextIdP subCommand returns authenticatorFederationManagement response with following parameters:
rpId (0x01): Text String, relying party id. idpId (0x02): Text String, the content of fedEntity.

section.name: CTAP2 Status codes
section.t: This extension also introduces a new status code that has to be added to the table of available status codes.

texttable.c: There are no available IdPs. This can have two reasons: 1) there are really no discoverable credentials marked as federation key 2) there are federation credentials that have a credential protection policy greater than optional but the client didn't provide a pinUvAuthToken.
